Expectation1: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation1: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: I glance at the clock, heart pounding. The church bell rings in the distance, calling the faithful to Sunday worship. As a Christian, I know I should be there, joining the congregation in prayer and song, feeling the comfort of community and the presence of God. I promised myself I’d go this week, to reconnect and show my commitment. But as a citizen, I can’t ignore the ballot measure that will shape the future of my block. The polling place is just down the street, but it closes in two hours. I feel the weight of responsibility—my neighbors are counting on every vote, and I’ve always believed in participating in civic life. My phone buzzes with a reminder from the church group, while a text from a neighbor urges me to vote. I stand in my hallway, torn, the expectations of faith and citizenship pulling me in opposite directions. My chest tightens as I realize I can’t do both.
